name: Saint Michael the Archangel
description: Saint Michael the Archangel (Hebrew: Mikha'el, 'Who is like God?') is the commander of the heavenly armies, the champion who cast Satan from heaven, and the defender of God's people. In Scripture, he appears as 'one of the chief princes' (Daniel 10:13), the 'great prince who protects your people' (Daniel 12:1), and the leader of the angelic forces who defeat the dragon in the War in Heaven (Revelation 12:7-9). In Jude 1:9, he contends with the devil over the body of Moses. Michael is venerated across Judaism, Christianity, and Islam as the supreme warrior angel. He is invoked for protection in spiritual warfare, deliverance from evil, and defense of the dying. The Roman Catholic Church celebrates his feast on September 29 (Michaelmas), and he is patron of soldiers, police, and the sick.
title: Archangel Michael - Christian Mythology
symbols: Aeons - Celestial warriors in Gnostic cosmology
Archons - Cosmic warfare against evil powers
Divine Combat - Spiritual battle for liberation
War in Heaven - Apocalyptic struggle narratives
domains: Protector of Israel and the Church
roles: Michael is associated with the end times and the Last Judgment. In some traditions, he is depicted holding the scales that weigh souls, determining their eternal destiny. He is also believed to sound the trumpet announcing the resurrection of the dead and Christ's Second Coming.
summary: Also known as ⚔️ Archangel Michael. Associated with "Who is like God?" (Hebrew: מִיכָאֵל, Mikha'el), Commander of Heaven's armies, Protector of Israel and the Church, Defeater of Satan. Known as "Who is like God?" (Hebrew: מִיכָאֵל. Symbolized by sword.

biblicalNarratives: War in Heaven - Michael and his angels fight against the dragon (Revelation 12:7-9)
Guardian of Israel - 'Michael, the great prince who protects your people' (Daniel 12:1)
Dispute over Moses' body - contending with the devil (Jude 1:9)
Vision to Daniel - appearing as 'one of the chief princes' (Daniel 10:13, 21)
mythology_content.theologicalRole: Michael is the commander of God's armies, the defender against Satan and evil forces, and the protector of God's people. He embodies divine justice and military strength in service of righteousness.

angels.function: Commander of heavenly armies, defender against Satan, protector of Israel and the Church

worship.liturgicalRole: Invoked for protection, exorcism, and spiritual warfare
feastDays: September 29 - Feast of Saints Michael, Gabriel, and Raphael (Michaelmas)
May 8 - Apparition of Saint Michael (in some traditions)
prayers: Prayer to Saint Michael the Archangel (composed by Pope Leo XIII)

biblical: Daniel 10:13, 21 - Michael as 'one of the chief princes'
Daniel 12:1 - Michael as protector of Israel
Jude 1:9 - Dispute with the devil over Moses' body
Revelation 12:7-9 - War in Heaven against the dragon
apocryphal: 1 Enoch - Michael as one of the four archangels
2 Enoch - Michael's role in the heavenly court
Testament of Abraham - Michael as psychopomp
patristic: Pope Leo XIII's Prayer to Saint Michael (1886)

extendedContent.etymology: From Hebrew 'Mikha'el' meaning 'Who is like God?' - a rhetorical question asserting God's supremacy. The name itself is a battle cry against Satan, who sought to be 'like the Most High' (Isaiah 14:14).
iconography: Depicted as a warrior in armor with sword and shield
Often shown defeating Satan (depicted as dragon or serpent)
Scales of justice for weighing souls at the Last Judgment
Military attire with wings, sometimes bearing a banner
Standing victorious with foot on the dragon's head
Bearing the Book of Life or leading souls to heaven
apparitions: Monte Gargano, Italy (490 AD) - Established the sanctuary of Saint Michael
Castel Sant'Angelo, Rome (590 AD) - Appearing to Pope Gregory the Great, ending a plague
Mont Saint-Michel, France (708 AD) - Appearing to Bishop Aubert of Avranches
extendedContent.spiritualWarfare: Michael represents God's power to overcome evil. He is invoked in prayers for protection, exorcisms, and defense against spiritual attacks. Pope Leo XIII composed the Prayer to Saint Michael after a vision of coming spiritual battles.

crossCultural.judaism: Michael is the guardian angel of Israel (Daniel 12:1), one of the four chief angels, and defender of the Jewish people. The Talmud (Berakhot 4b) places him at the right hand of God's throne.
crossCultural.christianity: Venerated as a saint in Catholic, Orthodox, Anglican, and Lutheran traditions. Chief of all angels, defender of the Church, and leader in the final battle against Satan.
crossCultural.islam: Known as Mikail, one of the four archangels. He is responsible for providing nourishment to bodies and souls, and control of nature and rain.

extendedContent.lastJudgment: In both Eastern and Western tradition, Michael has a role at the Last Judgment. He is often depicted weighing souls in the balance or leading the righteous to paradise. This psychopomp function appears in the Testament of Abraham and medieval art.

primarySources.content: 'The prince of the kingdom of Persia withstood me twenty-one days, but Michael, one of the chief princes, came to help me... There is none who contends by my side against these except Michael, your prince.'
'At that time shall arise Michael, the great prince who has charge of your people. And there shall be a time of trouble, such as never has been since there was a nation till that time.'
'But when the archangel Michael, contending with the devil, was disputing about the body of Moses, he did not presume to pronounce a blasphemous judgment, but said, "The Lord rebuke you."'

'Now war arose in heaven, Michael and his angels fighting against the dragon. And the dragon and his angels fought back, but he was defeated, and there was no longer any place for them in heaven. And the great dragon was thrown down, that ancient serpent, who is called the devil and Satan.'

oldTestament: Daniel 10:13 - Michael as 'one of the chief princes' helping against the prince of Persia
Daniel 12:1 - 'Michael, the great prince who has charge of your people'
newTestament: Jude 1:9 - Michael disputes with Satan over Moses' body
Revelation 12:7-9 - Michael leads the war in heaven against the dragon
apocryphal: 1 Enoch 20:5 - Michael as one of the four archangels
1 Enoch 40:9 - Michael set over the best part of mankind
Testament of Abraham - Michael as psychopomp and advocate
2 Enoch 22:6 - Michael as intercessor for humanity
War Scroll (1QM) - Michael as 'Prince of Light' leading the Sons of Light

prayers.prayerToSaintMichael: Saint Michael the Archangel, defend us in battle. Be our protection against the wickedness and snares of the devil. May God rebuke him, we humbly pray, and do thou, O Prince of the heavenly hosts, by the power of God, cast into hell Satan, and all the evil spirits, who prowl about the world seeking the ruin of souls. Amen.
prayers.origin: Composed by Pope Leo XIII in 1886 after a reported mystical experience. Originally recited after Low Mass until 1964.
prayers.chaplet: The Chaplet of Saint Michael consists of nine salutations to the nine choirs of angels, honoring Michael as their prince.

iconographicTradition.byzantine: Depicted as a military commander with labarum or spear, often labeled 'The Archistrategos' (Supreme Commander)
iconographicTradition.western: Shown in armor defeating the dragon, or with scales weighing souls
iconographicTradition.ethiopian: Particularly venerated; monthly feast on the 12th of each Ethiopian month

patronages: The sick, especially those near death
Vatican City, Germany, France, and many other nations and cities
